>>180441787
Some do, “runners” but they’re only recently infected. Also they are never really in hoards (except until the 2nd game).

The different kinds are:
>runners (run, can see, die by headshot)
>clickers (amble, cannot see, have radar, bullet sponges, kill on contact without a shiv)
>bloaters (late-stage infected, full finger armour head to toe, throw explosive spores, instant kill on contact, require lots of ammunition to take down)
>stalkers (live in damp areas with water, mixture between runners and clickers, retain some intelligence and actively hunt humans if they are aware of them)
>rat king (only one known to exist at centre of outbreak, dozens of infected all attached together in a giant mushroom ball, fast, instant kill on contact, takes lots of ammunition to take down)

Instead give us vignettes of this co world's with stand alone stories. A collection of short stories if you will. Sick of seeing drawn out stories that tell very little and have to make up extra conflict to keep the run time.

But no one has the balls. Accept death and robots I guess

I always thought of Clown World as this modern thing, but honestly the more I've pondered it over the last few years the more I realize it's existed forever. Obviously the messages weren't able to spread to as many people in the idk 1600s, but there was still a clown world within each culture/civilization, there were still freaks and psychos and pure good/pure evil. Like there were plenty of people back then that would chop people up and display it proudly, maybe it was a warrior showing off his kill or maybe it was some insane "shaman" showing off something gruesome as a form of humor. As someone else clarified Gotham's first season was the only one with the villain of the week formula. With season 2 they changed the format so the show actually has a story. Typically they split each half of the seasons into their own arc. 2A Dumas, 2B, Hugo Strange, 3A Mad Hatter, 3B Court of Owls, 4A Sofia Falcone and Professor Pyg, 4B Proto Joker. Gotham's weakness was typically blitzing through stories too fast. It's the only 13+ episode person season show I can think of that actually doesn't have any filler. If anything so much shit happens they sometimes should've had more episodes so things weren't so rushed.

No. The show was not always campy, especially not in S1. The show very much stuck to it's own basic noir premise into mid S2, relying mostly on mystery plots, forgoing action for a more slower-paced approach to plot resolutions, especially as it conferred the intertwining agendas of the mafioso Penguin/Falconi/Marone/Mooney.
As i said, anons here found that boring, and laud the action oriented change of pace as the show's own renaissance. I disagree with that, because it was entirely bereft of substance and betrays its own noir intents that built it, marred in the ridiculous changes to Barbara Kean throughout the seasons that border on soap opera tier, and by 4th seasons Penguin is already a faggot and the feminazi League of Assassins plot is ramping up.
It became self-indulgent and pandering, completely different from its, in my opinion, interesting premise. Indeed, becomes very teenybobber and as ridiculous as David Tennant's scenery-chewing tongue flicking in Jessica Jones.

It manifests differently. TOS uses the of Girl of the Week trope in a way not really found in ENT. TOS also did costume stuff (pic related) that, although perhaps seems tame nowadays, rather pushed the censors back then. On the subject of miniskirts in TOS most of the actresses apparently wanted to wear skirts and in general it is just more reflective of fashion at the time than anything else. Come ENT you don't have the female crew in miniskirts and outside of T'Pol both male and female crew wear those jumpsuit-things; yet, T'Pol's wardrobe of catsuit (which just follows on from Seven in VOY) and skimpy silk pyjamas clearly is for fanservice. With ENT you also had very sexually fanservicey stuff like decon (specifically them in their underwear and rubbing gel on each other), Trip & T'pol massaging each other, T'Pol undressing infront of Trip and Trip & TPol having sex in the shower - which is all stuff which would have bot gotten passed the censor in the time of TOS. Both are reflective of their respective time, TOS coming about in a liberalising period and ENT trying to compete in a era nudity/sex were common.

posts.com:
Why did sitcoms become so uncreative after the 60s?
In the 50s, sitcoms were all just married couples/families. But then in the 60s, sitcoms were like
>an inept spy for an organization more secret than the FBI or CIA who somehow always gets his man in the end
>an astronaut finds a genie in a bottle and takes her home to be his live-in bangmaid
>a reporter finds a martian and they live together as bros and get into wacky shenanigans
>a man marries a woman and later finds out she and her entire family are secretly witches
then at some point, in like the 70s or 80s, someone said "no, go back to the 50s format for sitcoms" and they all became about families or people with regular jobs again. Yawn. It wasn't until the 90s that sitcoms started to have wackier premises again, and even then the majority are still just regular people

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>180440377
>The frame is exposed to so much light that every single bad pixel will be noticeable.
It's not the exposure values, it's the lack of contrast in frame that makes it look amateurish. It's shot flat with a lack of contrast to make on the fly changes to the shot in post possible/easier. You're kind of right in your first statement but not for the reason you seem to imply. It might look better because using film is more expensive and usually requires the production to adopt a preproduction oriented workflow instead of the modern "we'll fix it in post" attitude. When filming the shot is the expensive part you have to be more careful and thoughtful with how you setup, and execute each shot. Preplanning, practicing execution and getting the shot to 75% in camera on the day in the first place makes for a much better outcome than shooting thousands of hours of bullshit then dumping that on the fx house's desk and expecting them to turn a bunch of takes of a couple of fumbled sloppy fightscenes that were only rehearsed for 2 hours into hong kong golden era kungfu tier sequences.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hidden Gems - by year

Fido (2006) (English) - This is a comedy with horror elements. There isn't very many movies like Fido. It's like Leave it to Beaver meets Land of the Dead.

The Signal (2007) (English) - This movie has an odd effect on women that I have never seen before and have never been able to replicate. Watch this movie by yourself first, then watch the movie with the women in your life and observe their reaction. It makes them extremely uncomfortable and some girls have even requested I turn it off because it's so uncomfortable for them to watch.

Pontypool (2008) (English) - Much of this movie will be theater of the mind as you listen to the smooth buttery voice of radio host Grant Mazzy. I'll just leave this quote here "a screaming baby... coming from Mary Galt's eldest son's last dying gasps. Mazzy in the morning...".

Splinter (2008) (English) - This movie does a great job creating an isolated atmosphere. The special effects are awesome and the acting is great.

Carriers (2009) (English) - A great character driven post-apocalyptic virus film.

Rammbock: Berlin Undead(Siege of the Dead) (2010) (German) - When I first saw the title of this movie I thought it was going to be a crappy B movie. However, I was pleasantly surprised to see a well put together movie with great atmosphere and emotion.

Hell (2011) (German) - Post-apocalyptic future where the sun is hot as fuck.

Juan of the Dead(Juan de los muertos) (2011) (Spanish) - The thing that makes a great zombie film isn't the zombies. It's the threat that the zombies impose and how the characters react to it. Juan of the Dead is mostly a comedy with some intense moments with very likeable characters.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
State of Emergency (2011) (English) - A good slow paced zombie film with a great atmosphere of isolation and dread.

The Battery (2012) (English) - Proof that you do not a billion dollar budget to make a great film. The Battery walks the fine line between comedy and horror without tainting either in the process.

Cockneys vs Zombies (2012) (English) - While the title may turn you off because it sounds like a terrible B movie, it is actually a really well made film. Mostly a comedy with horror elements. I found myself rewatching it multiple times just to look at the beautiful scenery of a place I'll likely never get a chance visit.

I Am a Hero (2016) (Japanese) - A respectfully done, condensed version of the manga of the same name. If you're into the Japanese style zombies that contort, run like dogs, and have supernatural strength, this is for you and likely the manga as well.

The Last Days(Los últimos días) (2013) (Spanish) - A post-apocalyptic movie where people can't go outside. They'll die within seconds.

The Fare (2018) (English) - A strange tale of a taxi driver who keeps picking up the same passanger on a loop.

Coherence (2013) (English) - A bit slow and bad acting in the beginning but once things pick up and the mystery presents itself its a fun ride from there.

On the other hand, he was an unsightly, ghastly-pale wretch of a child with a poor upbringing, being the mongrel cast-off from a rich pureblood lineage. Undoubtedly mistreated not only by Potter, but his Slytherin peers as well. His options were always going to be constricted by the seething resentment he felt towards the world.

>>180433862
>consumed as a child
To a degree. But the early phase of any persuasive technique begins with "matching". This is when the sales pitch hasn't really begun, and the salesman/conman/commie/freemason/jew is building up his bona fides with the target. By "matching" what that person already likes and naturally responds to. Only later, when confidence is won, do they start weaving in small nudges and suggestions that maybe, just maybe, the target should try following the salesman away into a new area where great new, exciting things await. This part if called "leading". The Pied Piper concept. Drug dealer's first-taste is free, etc.

The "nudging" has been going on for centuries if not millennia. Leading us away from our roots. But only at certain points in repeating cycles do they attempt the brute-force leading method they're attempting now. Where the noise completely overrides the signal.

>Teenager who thinks he's a rebel fighting the wokies
